newsitem.title: USA: U.S. not denying reports of China rights deal.
newsitem.headline: U.S. not denying reports of China rights deal.

text.p: The United States on Thursday declined to deny news reports that it was discussing with China a package of measures intended to defuse tensions over human rights.
"I simply can't confirm, will not confirm, don't want to confirm any of these stories," State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns said, adding: "I'm not in a position to confirm it or deny it."

The New York Times reported on Thursday that Washington was talking to Beijing about a package on human rights that could include release or medical parole of noted dissidents, prison visits to Chinese detainees by the Internatonal Committee of the Red Cross and a "more structured channel" to raise rights issues with China.

Some of these were agreed to before but not implemented due to a sharp downturn in Sino-American relations after the United States in 1995 granted a visa to Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui, outraging Beijing.

In exchange for the human rights moves, the United States might be willing to drop its co-sponsorship of an annual United Nations resolution condemning Chinese human rights practices, the New York Times said.

The newspaper also reported that in June, President Bill Clinton sent a private letter to Chinese President Jiang Zemin offering to grant China permanent "most favoured nation" trading status in return for a concession on improving Beijing's human rights record.

Concerning U.S. intentions on the annual U.N. resolution, Burns said: "...we evaluate the human rights situation in China on an on-going basis. And we'll continue to evaluate it on an on-going basis, to determine whether or not resolutions are helpful or not helpful, important or not important."

He reiterated that Secretary of State Warren Christopher planned to go ahead with a trip to Beijing next month despite China's sentencing to 11 years in prison on Wednesday of well-regarded pro-democracy activist Wang Dan.
He also reasserted that Christopher plans to raise with senior Chinese officials Wang and other rights cases.
But Burns declined to say for sure if Clinton -- if he is re-elected next Tuesday -- would go ahead with a proposed exchange of summits with Jiang.

Christopher several months ago called for an exchange of high-level visits -- his trip on Nov 18-21 is part of that series -- including summits. He argued the need for engaging, rather than isolating, China, whose importance is viewed as growing in the 21st century.
Whether a U.S.-China summit is held "is up for the president to decide after the (U.S.) election," Burns said.
